_metadata.description: Culture-level genetic profiles for ancient populations
sources: Haak et al. 2015 - Massive migration from the steppe
Olalde et al. 2018 - The Beaker phenomenon
Lazaridis et al. 2014/2016 - Ancient human genomes
Mathieson et al. 2015 - Genome-wide patterns of selection
_metadata.notes: Genetic profiles based on published ancient DNA studies. Ancestry percentages are approximate and vary by individual/region.

whg.name: Western Hunter-Gatherers
whg.description: The indigenous population of Western and Central Europe before the arrival of farmers. Descended from people who survived the Last Glacial Maximum in southern refugia (Iberia, Italy, Balkans). Had a distinctive phenotype: dark skin combined with blue eyes.
whg.technology: Mesolithic microliths, dugout canoes, fishing equipment

rs12913832.note: Blue eyes - nearly fixed in WHG

whg.modern_legacy: Contributed ~10-20% of ancestry to modern Northern Europeans, less in South. Blue eye gene originated here.

ehg.name: Eastern Hunter-Gatherers
ehg.description: Hunter-gatherers of Eastern Europe and the Russian steppe. Mix of ancient West Eurasian and Ancient North Eurasian (ANE) ancestry. Later merged with Caucasus farmers to form the Yamnaya.

ancestry_components.note: EHG itself is ~75% West Eurasian, ~25% ANE

rs1426654.note: Variable skin - some light skin allele

ehg.modern_legacy: Major contribution to Yamnaya and through them to modern Europeans. ~20-40% of European ancestry traces through EHG-derived populations.

anf.name: Anatolian Neolithic Farmers
anf.description: The first farmers, originating in the Fertile Crescent and spreading across Europe via two routes: along the Mediterranean coast and up the Danube. Replaced ~90% of WHG ancestry in most of Europe within 2,000 years.
anf.technology: Pottery, polished stone tools, mud-brick architecture, weaving

rs4988235.note: STILL lactose intolerant despite cattle herding

anf.modern_legacy: ~20-40% of modern European ancestry. Brought light skin to Europe. Y-haplogroup G2a was dominant before Steppe migrations but now rare.

yamnaya.name: Yamnaya (Steppe Pastoralists)
yamnaya.description: Bronze Age pastoralists from the Pontic-Caspian steppe. One of the most impactful populations in human history. Spread Indo-European languages, brought new technologies, and massively transformed European genetics in the Bronze Age.
yamnaya.technology: Wheeled vehicles, bronze metallurgy, horse riding/driving

ancestry_components.note: Mix of Eastern HG and Caucasus/Iranian farmers

rs4988235.note: Mostly lactose intolerant - surprising for herders

yamnaya.modern_legacy: ~40-60% of Northern European ancestry, ~20-40% in Southern Europe. Brought R1b/R1a to dominance. Indo-European languages now spoken by 3 billion people.

bell_beaker.name: Bell Beaker Culture
bell_beaker.description: Bronze Age culture defined by distinctive bell-shaped pottery. The Bell Beaker expansion into Britain was one of the most dramatic population replacements in prehistory - replacing ~90% of Neolithic British ancestry within a few centuries.
bell_beaker.technology: Bronze metalworking, archery, distinctive pottery, early wool textiles
bell_beaker.modern_legacy: Direct ancestors of modern British/Irish. R1b-P312 dominates Western European Y-chromosomes today because of this expansion.

corded_ware.name: Corded Ware Culture
corded_ware.description: Contemporary with early Bell Beaker but primarily northern European distribution. Named for cord-impressed pottery decoration. Associated with the spread of R1a and possibly early Germanic/Baltic/Slavic Indo-European branches.
corded_ware.technology: Stone battle axes, cord-decorated pottery, early bronze
corded_ware.modern_legacy: Contributed significantly to Northern/Eastern European ancestry. R1a spread with Corded Ware, now dominant in Eastern Europe, Central Asia, South Asia.

unetice.name: Únětice Culture
regions: Central Europe (Bohemia, Moravia, Germany, Poland, Austria)
unetice.description: Early Bronze Age culture of Central Europe. Famous for sophisticated bronze metallurgy and the Nebra Sky Disc, the oldest known realistic representation of the cosmos.
unetice.technology: Advanced bronze working, gold working, amber trade
unetice.modern_legacy: Ancestors of later Central European Bronze/Iron Age populations.

british_bronze_age.name: British Bronze Age
british_bronze_age.description: Bronze Age population of Britain and Ireland, descended from Bell Beaker migrants. Built the final phases of Stonehenge, developed sophisticated bronze metalworking, and established trade networks across Europe.
british_bronze_age.technology: Bronze tools and weapons, gold ornaments, tin mining and trade
british_bronze_age.modern_legacy: Direct ancestors of Iron Age Britons and ultimately modern British people.

hallstatt_culture.name: Hallstatt Culture (Early Celtic)
hallstatt_culture.description: Early Iron Age culture of Central Europe, often considered the first identifiable 'Celtic' culture. Named for the salt mines at Hallstatt, Austria. Elite burials with wagons, imports from Mediterranean.
hallstatt_culture.lifestyle: Settled farming, salt mining, long-distance trade
hallstatt_culture.technology: Iron working, salt mining, wagon burials, Mediterranean imports
hallstatt_culture.modern_legacy: Foundation population for La Tène Celts who spread across Europe.

la_tene_culture.name: La Tène Culture (Late Celtic)
la_tene_culture.description: Height of Celtic civilization. Named for the La Tène archaeological site in Switzerland. Distinctive art style, expanded across Europe. Gauls, Britons, Galatians, Celtiberians.
la_tene_culture.technology: Advanced iron smithing, chainmail, distinctive art, oppida

typical_phenotype.hair: Variable (Celts described as tall, often red/blond haired by Romans)

la_tene_culture.modern_legacy: Immediate ancestors of Roman-period Celtic peoples. Celtic languages survive in Ireland, Wales, Scotland, Brittany.

british_iron_age.name: British Iron Age
british_iron_age.description: Iron Age inhabitants of Britain before Roman conquest. Built hill forts, had druids, used Celtic languages. Largely continuous with Bronze Age population with some Continental Celtic influence.
british_iron_age.technology: Iron working, chariot warfare, roundhouse architecture
british_iron_age.modern_legacy: Major contributors to modern British ancestry. R1b-L21 dominates Ireland and Western Britain today.

anglo_saxon.name: Anglo-Saxons
anglo_saxon.description: Germanic migrants who settled in Britain after Roman withdrawal. Angles, Saxons, Jutes, and Frisians. Established the foundations of England, English language, and English culture.

ancestry_components.note: Mixed with indigenous British, highly regional variation

anglo_saxon.modern_legacy: ~25-40% of English ancestry is Anglo-Saxon (varies by region - higher in East, lower in West/North). English language and culture.

viking.name: Vikings (Norse)
viking.description: Scandinavian seafarers who raided, traded, and settled across Europe and beyond. Established the Danelaw in England, founded Dublin, colonized Iceland and Greenland, reached North America.

ancestry_components.note: Danish Vikings more diverse; Norwegian Vikings more homogeneous

viking.modern_legacy: ~3-6% of English ancestry, higher in northern/eastern regions. Significant contribution to Scottish, Irish ancestry. Founded Iceland's population.

pictish.name: Picts
pictish.description: Indigenous people of northern and eastern Scotland. Known for distinctive carved symbol stones. United with Scots to form Kingdom of Alba/Scotland in 843 CE. Their language is lost.

ancestry_components.note: Largely continuous with Iron Age Britons

pictish.modern_legacy: Absorbed into Scottish population. Contributed to modern Scottish ancestry, especially in northeast Scotland.

roman_britain.name: Roman Britain
roman_britain.description: Britain under Roman rule. Mix of native Britons, Roman settlers from across the Empire, and their descendants. Diverse population in urban centers like London and York.

ancestry_components.note: Urban centers more diverse than rural areas

roman_britain.modern_legacy: Little direct genetic impact - most genetic change came from later Anglo-Saxon and Viking migrations.

iran_neolithic.name: Iranian Neolithic
iran_neolithic.description: Independent development of farming in the Zagros mountains. Ancestral to Caucasus populations and contributed significantly to Yamnaya ancestry, and through them to modern Europeans.
iran_neolithic.modern_legacy: ~25% of Yamnaya ancestry came from Iran/Caucasus-related populations. Major contribution to South/Central Asian ancestry.

levant_neolithic.name: Levantine Neolithic
levant_neolithic.description: The cradle of agriculture. First domestication of wheat, barley, and many animals. Pre-Pottery Neolithic cultures built some of the world's oldest settlements including Jericho.
levant_neolithic.technology: Ground stone tools, early architecture, plastered skulls
levant_neolithic.modern_legacy: Ancestral to all European farmers via Anatolia. Foundation of Western civilization's agricultural base.
